ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: It was my favorite class of the semester!

Peter spent way too much time covering "housekeeping" issues--when we needed to take our quizzes, when our readings were due, presentation order, etc. He needs to have a more clear syllibus at the start of class so that if we have questions we can ask but otherwise all important information is in the syllibus.the quizzes we took were not helpful and i didn't learn anything from them.

Q 12: I think this course will undergo a lot of change since its new, but I wish we'd kept our energy-related lectures.Q 7: I think we should figure out a way to still teach students to evaluate a building

Overall, thought this was a good class. I think sometime we were trying to cover a little too much information too quickly. I realize this is a survey course, but some of the lectures felt rushed. Too much time in class was spelt dealing with logistics (sometimes 20+ minutes). Logistics should be dealt with via email/classes v2. Class time is too valuable.
the instructor already provided an in-class course eval which i completed extensively. i won't be repeating it here.

Yost is one of the finest instructors I've ever met. He cares a great deal about the subject matter andhis students. FES sorely needs to have a class about Green Building from a practitioner's angle, and this course and instructor filled that gap very well.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Some guest lectures are awesome but some are just not my thing.
Knowledgeable professor, particularly well versed in building science

At first I thought the work load was going to be too heavy and the lectures perhaps too technical, however early on it became very clear that this course was going to provide the perfect sampling of contemporary green building topics at multiple scales and the instructor very quickly adapted the technical level of the class to the expertise (or lack thereof) of the students. The access to the Green Building website and the quizzes was a great way to summarize the reading for each section and quantify the level of comprehension on each topic.
Peter brought in a lot of real world knowledge gained from his professional career.
I really valued hearing from a practitioner.
tours of yale buildings.
The actual lectures, Bill Reed's talk
Great class for students who want to learn about how buildings function but have no background, whatsoever. The readings and lectures can get technical at times, but overall, very helpful.
This course was taught by a practitioner and provided a great knowledge base for how buildings work. It is not a course about renewable energy systems, but rather focuses more on building science.

Best part of the class is the 'in the field' experience that Peter brings to the classroom. This class offers technical information on how buildings function that is simply not available in any other class offered at FES.
The guest lectures were interesting and informative.
The project presentations, also access to buildinggreen.com
Everything! There is a green building courses!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The instructor really needs to tailor the learning material to the students' knowledge level about green building. I just cannot finish the assigned reading for each week. There are too many professional phrases that I don't understand. The lectures about insulation, windows, building sciences are too technical for me.
Can be slightly disorganized

The only addition I would suggest would be perhaps a field trip to off campus facilities of different scales (residential, commercial, industrial) buildings that are great examples of BMP's in green building design.

This class was designed to be a survey class, and it was exactly that. However, I think there needs to be a focus at the beginning (first four or five weeks) that starts with an in-depth of the fundamentals...i.e. something very technical but also very expository. The class sort of did this, but I think it could go further. After the first month or so, I would want to be well-versed in all aspects of green-buildings that can be cross-applied to other green building genres.
Discussion of logistics took up a bit too much time at the beginning of each class, and communications regarding due dates felt a bit disorganized.
organization.
in-class activities and scheduling of assignmentsI wish transformation was a stronger theme in the class

Instructor tries to pack A LOT into the day's agenda. I think the course would have been better if the instructor wasn't so ambitious in trying to fit so much into the time we have together. Given the amount of reading we had to do for each lecture, perhaps designating 1-hour discussion sections just to review readings would be better than trying to do it during lecture time WITH guest speakers.

Readings. Assignments. Syllabus.Reduce the amount of time external speakers get to talk. Course and syllabus and discussion sessions need to get more specific and detail oriented. Green buildings include a lot of technology hence more specific technical topics must be a part of this course.

This was the first time this course was taught. As such, it was sometimes a bit unorganized in terms of assignment requirements, due dates, etc. However, this is expected of any new course. Peter was flexible and helpful in responding to any issues.Also, there were a few too many guest lectures. Although the lectures were interesting and applicable, it would have been helpful to either have fewer or shorter guest lectures. I found that they detracted from our ability to discuss course readings and concepts as a class.
Organization. Obviously, this was the first time the course was taught, but the course needs to be more organized. Syllabus changed a ton of times, too much time spent on logistics in class, etc.
It covered too much material for a one semester course. I think having a more streamlined syllabus would make it more clear and comprehensible.
Have maybe two fewer guest lecturers, don't spend as much time at the beginning of classes on "administrative" stuff that could be done through email.
Nothing

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Due to the eligibility of the guest speakers, at times the course topics would get out of sync with the syllabus, but that was certainly not an issue to the students, since most of these topics were new to us and did not have any preconceived notions about what order of lectures would have been most effective. SInce this was the first course of this type at Yale F&ES I think it was a great first step and can see that the order and depth of the topics will evolve very logically over time.
n/a
N/A
More real life case studies should be a part of this course.
Field trips, as in the building tours, were well integrated and very illuminating. Would have been nice to get more training on the assessment worksheets.
Nothing

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Great primer on how buildings actually work

I believe that this course fits into many of the current programs here at F&ES since buildings are the largest energy using/co2 generating structures on the planet. With the growing global population, there exists a unique and urgent need for these structures to function efficiently without continued burdens on our resources. This course provides the understanding of applied green building design and function not currently provided at F&ES by any other course.
I study energy, so this is a good subfield to be versed in.
i'm interested in energy efficiency.

This was a valuable course as I prepare for a career in institutional sustainability management. Although I don't intend to focus on buildings in my career, it's important to understand how they work if you're looking to manage energy use.

I'm interested in designing/improving utility-scale energy efficiency programs. Improving the energy efficiency of buildings is a main priority for these programs, so this course was relevant in that respect. I would have liked to see more of a focus on energy efficiency through guest speakers, etc.
It is an important related topic to my focus on energy systems.
It fits very very very well

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Just because my interest in green building

I have an interest in the impact that our built environment has on the functioning of urban ecosystems. This course gave me a greater understanding of how the structures in our communities can be designed and redesigned to enhance energy efficiency and also provide a platform to manage heat island effect, stormwater runoff, habitat re-creation, and decrease resource overuse by retrofitting the buildings we currently inhabit.
See above.
I am interested in the built environment.
interested in sustainable building and energy efficiency.

To better understand how buildings work. I got a bit of that but still feel we overlooked important parts, like mechanical systems. I think the future structure of the course should seek to answer that question more so than anything else; which we addressed at times and skirted around at others.

I'm interested in urban and regional planning, and the material flow of resources. Buildings are resource pools that hold "stock" for several decades in the built environment, so I thought it would be useful to know a thing or two about energy and material efficiency in buildings.
This was a course that I randomly shopped. It turned out to be one of my favorites.
I'm generally interested in green buildings and very interested elements of buildings that have a significant impact on energy efficiency.
It is an important related topic to my focus on energy systems.
Professional Development

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Maybe. I don't know anything about green buildings before so I couldn't come up with any expectation about how much I want to learn about green buildings through this class.

Yes, exceeded my expectations. The lectures, readings, field trips and guest speakers have all enhanced my understanding of a variety of aspects of green building, particularly that the greenest buildings are the ones that are reused and retrofit for energy efficiency, rather than being torn down and replaced.

Sort of. I think there's some more technical stuff that I want to learn, but this class was not designed to meet (e.g. in-depth study of LEED or more advanced trainings on conducting energy audits, etc).
Yes, absolutely, and it confirmed my interest in architecture.
no
Partly. I learned things I didn't realize I wanted to learn, but feel I missed out on some things in place of guest lectures.
Yes, but I expected coming into this course thinking I'd learn enough to take the beginner's level of LEED exam... I don't think that was the purpose of this course.
About 40%
For the most part, yes. I would have liked to see more of a focus on mechanical systems (HVAC, etc.).
Yes.
Yes.
Yup and above.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It allowed us to each delve deeper into particular aspects of the topic than if we did the project on our own. It allowed for practice in applying our multidisciplinary skills to a single area of focus, allowing for different perspectives.
Working in a group allowed us to build synergies and develop/push ideas farther than I could've done on my own. There weren't really any disadvantages for our group.
advantages: split cool workdisadvantages: you have to compromise on things that you really care about and you don't always get your way/thigns aren't done exactly how you want them to be done.

Our topic turned out to be much broader than we anticipated, and we only realized this once we started looking for ways to approach the topic. I think we jumped into a lot of (useful) rabbit holes along the way, but I think the instructor probably should have been more active in helping us trim the topic early on.
I enjoyed the group work for this course. Each one of my group members brought a slightly different perspective to our project and it was great to bounce ideas off them.
It was fun and educational to work in a group. We accomplished more than if we had worked alone.
I came up with the topic and recruited my friends, and the goal was to deal with a very complex issue from an FES angle. I think we accomplished that.
Nope

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you are really into this topic, take it. If you are just curious about this topic, just wikipedia it.
Come into to the course with a clear idea of what you want to learn, and you can get a lot out of it.

The knowledge gained will be useful at both a professional and personal level. Weall live in buildings and each of us can make a difference by applying the knowledge learned from this class in a variety of situations.
Take it! It's a great course!

The instructor is highly knowledgeable and approachable, and has an amazing network of people whom he's happy to connect us to. He's very enthusiastic and intense, so come to lecture prepared with readings and questions to be more engaged with him.

This is a great course-- highly recommended to anyone who is looking to learn more about buildings. The final group project also allows you to explore any idea that might interest you as it relates to buildings and sustainability.

I would recommend this course. It's main weakness was the lack of organization, but I'm sure that will improve over time. Peter is a great guy with a ton of valuable information. You could tell he really care about the quality of the course, and I'm sure he'll put in a lot of time to improve it moving forward.
Take it. Green building is one of those topics that every MEM student should have a course in.
Take it
